turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Allegations of unlawful campaigning in the 2016 EU referendum.
turn.2: (In July 2019, it was also reported that Facebook would be fined around $5bn by the US Federal Trade Commission in relation to the same and related issues.)
turn.4: In February 2017, the Electoral Commission announced that it was investigating the spending of Stronger In and Vote Leave, along with smaller organisations, as they had not submitted all the necessary invoices, receipts, or details to back up their accounts.
turn.6: In the ensuing months, the Electoral Commission levied a number of fines on political parties and other campaign entities due to breaches of campaign finance rules during the referendum campaign, with a maximum possible fine under the law being £20,000. Fines of £1000 or more were: The DUP received £435,000 from the Constitutional Research Council.
turn.7: What did they do about that?
turn.8: The Electoral Commission fined the Constitutional Research Council for not declaring its donation to the DUP, the Electoral Commission found that the DUP had not itself broken electoral law.
turn.9: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.10: However, extensive press speculation continued, both on the question of the ultimate source(s) of the Constitutional Research Council's donation, and the legitimacy of its use, which included £282,000 for pro-Brexit advertising in the "Metro" newspaper, which does not circulate in Northern Ireland.
turn.12: In December 2018, the Good Law Project initiated judicial proceedings over the Commission's decision not to investigate further.
